General.preQuizText: Each of the research questions below has research question pitfalls. Select all the pitfalls that apply:

Questions.questionText: The big question to ask is, “when does a robot become too smart?” From this general question, I would like to derive several other questions such as, “should we be afraid of future robots?”, “do the benefits of A.I. outweigh the drawbacks?”, “how long until there are robots walking among us?” These questions will all help shape my research paper.

answers.feedBack: Correct! This student has asked multiple questions and will therefore struggle to find a consistent focus when they move to the information gathering stage. The individual questions are also closed and poorly suited to this kind of open investigation, e.g., the question “Do the benefits of A.I. outweigh the drawbacks?” can only be answered with a yes or no.

Questions.questionText: What are the main advantages of technology implemented into vehicles?

answers.feedBack: Correct! The question is too broad and the student needs to narrow their keywords, or else they will find it difficult to gather an appropriate amount of information. They might attempt to ask themselves the following questions and then revise their research question with the answers in mind: What kinds of technology? What kinds of vehicles? Advantages for whom: Motorists? Car manufacturers?

Questions.questionText: Is Steve Jobs the greatest tech CEO there ever was?

answers.feedBack: Correct! This question is closed and limited to only two possible answers: yes or no. It’s also flawed in other ways. First, it would be difficult to definitely determine the kind of ranking the question implies, because it would necessarily involve a lot of subjective interpretation. Second, the wording of the question is leading: it implies that the student has already taken for granted the greatness of Steve Jobs’ leadership. This is problematic because the assignment is designed to provide you with an opportunity to discover something new.
